questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman was diagnosed with osteoporosis four months back and was started on oral bisphosphonates. Which among the following is a biochemical marker of bone resorption that can be used to monitor her response to treatment?

choices.text: Serum propeptide of type I procollagen

questions.solution:
Serum and urine cross-linked C-telopeptide is a marker of bone resorption while the others are markers of bone formation.

The measurement of bone resorption using markers like serum cross-linked C-telopeptide before initiating therapy and 3–6 months after starting therapy provides an earlier estimate of patient response than bone densitometry evaluations. 

Biochemical markers measure the overall state of bone remodeling at a single point in time. They are primarily used for monitoring the response to treatment. Markers of bone resorption also help in the prediction of fracture risk in older individuals. 

Biochemical Markers of Bone Metabolism include:

Bone formation markers:

  1. Serum propeptide of type I procollagen
  2. Serum osteocalcin 
  3. Serum bone-specific alkaline phosphatase 

Bone resorption markers:

  1. Urine and serum cross-linked N-telopeptide 
  2. Urine and serum cross-linked C-telopeptide.

questions.text: The most common tendons to be affected in Volkmann's ischemic contracture (VIC) are ______

choices.text: Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor pollicis brevis (FPB)

questions.solution:
• In mild cases, fdp and fpl develop contractures, but in serious cases, all the finger and wrist flexors are affected.
  • Extending the wrist exaggerates the deformities and this is called as Volkmann’s sign.
  • Established VIC shows a claw hand deformity, volkmann’s sign, scarring of the forearm, neurological deficits, joint contractures and rarely gangrene.
  • Management involves 5 Ps: pressure to be relieved, pressure to be monitored, pulse to be recorded continuously, passive stretch test indicates severity, and putting the fracture back into its position.
  • Dynamic splinting, physiotherapy, arthrodesis, neurolysis, tendon transfers and seddon’s carpectomy & Max Page muscle slide operation are all a part of the treatment plan.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain and swelling in the wrist after a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, there was tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. A scaphoid fracture was suspected and an X-ray was performed which revealed the absence of a fracture line. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?

choices.text: Apply scaphoid cast and repeat X-ray 2 weeks later
Perform MRI to confirm the diagnosis

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of a fall on an outstretched hand followed by pain and swelling in the wrist with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox despite normal X-ray findings is suggestive of scaphoid fracture. The next best step in the management is to apply a scaphoid cast and perform an X-ray 2 weeks later.

All the cases of scaphoid fracture with high clinical suspicion with the absence of fracture line on X-ray should be treated with a scaphoid cast for 2 weeks. After 2 weeks X-ray is repeated. Sometimes, the fracture becomes visible at this stage, because of resorption of the fracture ends. If no fracture is seen even at 2 weeks, no further treatment is required. 

Scaphoid Fractures:

A scaphoid fracture is more common in young adults. Commonly, the fracture occurs through the waist of the scaphoid. Clinical features include pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist following a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, one may be able to elicit tenderness in the scaphoid fossa(anatomical snuff box). X-ray with an oblique view of the wrist is taken in addition to the anteroposterior and lateral views. Sometimes a fracture line is not visible on initial X-rays. If a fracture is strongly suspected, X-rays should be repeated after 2 weeks.

The affected hand is immobilized in a scaphoid cast for 3-4 months. The scaphoid cast extends from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads including the thumb up to the inter-phalangeal joint. The wrist is maintained in a little dorsiflexion and radial deviation (glass holding position). In widely displaced fractures, open reduction and internal fixation using a special compression screw (Herbert's screw) is required.

The common complications of scaphoid fracture include:

  • Non-union and delayed union
  • Avascular necrosis
  • Wrist osteoarthritis

questions.text: A young athlete complains of pain in both knees on standing up after sitting for a long duration. You observe that the patient winces with pain when you press the patella over the femur. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the findings given in the question, the most likely diagnosis is chondromalacia of the patella. The characteristic clinical presentation of this condition is pain on extending the knee after prolonged flexion, for example when standing up after prolonged sitting. This is also called as 'theatre sign'. 

Chondromalacia of the patella is common in active adolescents. It occurs due to mechanical overload of the patellofemoral joint, which leads to softening and fibrillation of the articular surface of the patella. Symptoms are aggravated on extending the knee after prolonged flexion, like standing up after sitting. Patellofemoral pain is elicited by pressing the patella against the femur and asking the patient to flex the quadriceps muscle. 

X-ray may show abnormal subluxation or tilting of the patella. Conservative management is done in most of the cases. Exercises are aimed at strengthening the medial part of quadriceps muscle to counteract the lateral tilting and subluxation of the patella.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient who met with a road traffic accident was treated with the implant shown in the given x-ray. In which of the following injuries is this implant used?
questions.solution:
This given x-ray shows a hip screw fixed with a side plate, which is a dynamic hip screw. This type of screw is used to treat stable inter-trochanteric fractures of the femur.

The management of intertrochanteric fractures of the femur depends on the displacement of the fractured fragments and the stability of the fracture. Two different types of implants are used based on the situation.

  • Undisplaced or stable intertrochanteric fractures are treated with dynamic hip screws. These are fitted with a side plate, which is an intramedullary implant lying outside the femur bone.
  • Displaced or unstable intertrochanteric fractures are treated using gamma nail or proximal femoral nail and intramedullary hip screw. These nails are intramedullary implants lying inside the medulla of the femur bone. The x-ray below shows this implant, which lies inside the medulla.

The preferred management of fracture shaft of femur is intra-medullary nailing or plating. None of these implants will involve the neck, as shown in the given x-ray.

questions.text: You are evaluating patients A and B with a congenital bone disorder caused by a defect in type 1 collagen synthesis. Both of them have a strong family history. Patient A has the following eye findings but patient B's eyes are normal. Which of the following features will be consistently present in all patients with the condition that patient A has?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a congenital bone disorder caused by a defect in type I collagen synthesis with a strong family history and the presence of blue sclera in patient A, as shown in the image above, is indicative of Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI). The only two characteristics consistently present in all patients with osteogenesis imperfecta are generalized osteoporosis and fractures.

Based on the subtypes of OI, only types I and II have blue sclera while III and IV have normal sclera.

Osteogenesis imperfecta, also called brittle bone disease, is an autosomal dominant disorder. There are 8 types of osteogenesis imperfecta. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

The main features are joints that are vulnerable to fracture (joint laxity), scleral alterations (blue sclera), dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness. Multiple bone fractures are a consequence of bone fragility. Bowing of the long bones, wormian bones, and multiple diaphyseal fractures of long bones with various stages are the common radiological findings that are observed. Management comprises the use of bisphosphonates, along with physiotherapy and walking aids.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient presents with muscle weakness, bone pain, and difficulty walking. Lab results show hypophosphatemia with normal calcium and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, and low 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Imaging identifies a small benign tumor in the skeletal extremities. Which of the following statements regarding this disease condition is correct?

FGF23- Fibroblast growth factor 23

choices.text: The condition involves increased activity of 1α-hydroxylase enzyme
Tumor resection is unlikely to reverse the biochemical abnormalities
The condition is associated with increased intestinal phosphate excretion
The condition involves reduced renal phosphate reabsorption

questions.solution:
The patient’s symptoms and lab findings of hypophosphatemia with normal calcium, low 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, and benign bone tumor in skeletal extremities suggest Tumor-Induced Osteomalacia (TIO). The condition involves reduced renal phosphate reabsorption. 

TIO is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome caused by the overproduction of fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) by a benign tumor, usually of mesenchymal origin such as hemangiopericytomas, fibromas, and giant cell tumors, often of the skeletal extremities or head. FGF23 plays a key role in regulating phosphate metabolism. FGF23 reduces phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubules and inhibits the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase, responsible for synthesizing active vitamin D (1,25(OH)2D). This hormone is produced primarily by osteocytes, and its levels are influenced by dietary phosphate intake. 

Treatment involves the removal of the tumor and supplementation with phosphate and vitamin D. The calcium-sensing receptor agonist, cinacalcet is also effective by reducing PTH-mediated phosphaturia.

questions.text: A cervical radiograph of a patient involved in a road traffic accident is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hangman's fracture.

The given cervical radiograph shows fracture of the pedicles of the C2 vertebra with an anterior translation of C2 over the C3 vertebra thus giving the diagnosis of hangman's fracture.

The mechanism of a traumatic hangman's fracture is hyperextension due to force to the forehead along with axial loading. It was incorrectly referred to previously as hangman's fracture due to the distractive force and death from spinal cord injury in judicial hanging. This results in anterior translation of the C2 vertebra over the C3 vertebra associated with pars interarticularis fracture of C2 which may extend up to the posterior body wall. Neurologic injury is unusual. 

Treatment:

Undisplaced fractures can be treated using semi-rigid arthrosis until united. Reduction with in-line traction followed by a semi-rigid collar in fractures with dislocation more than 3.5mm without kyphotic angulation. In cases of C2/C3 facet dislocation, open reduction and stabilization are required.

Other options:

Option A- Dens fracture is the fracture of the odontoid process of the C2 vertebra.

Option C- Clay shoveller’s fracture is the avulsion of the spinous process of the seventh cervical vertebra.

Option D- Jefferson's fracture is the burst fracture of the ring of the C1 vertebra/Atlas.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of gradually progressive swelling and pain over the upper portion of the tibia for the past 5-6 months. An x-ray of the affected area is shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the radiograph showing an area of lucency with sclerotic borders, is suggestive of Brodie's abscess. An open biopsy with curettage is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Brodie's abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. The organism mostly involved would be Staphylococcus aureus. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

Differential diagnosis: The clinical features and x-ray can mimic several other conditions.

  • Cystic tuberculosis
  • Eosinophilic granuloma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Investigations: 

  • WBC counts and blood cultures are usually normal.
  • ESR may be elevated in some cases. 
  • The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity. 
  • MRI may be helpful in diagnosis.
  • Open biopsy with curettage is indicated if there is any doubt in the diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) intravenous for 4-5 days, followed by oral administration for another 6 weeks; healing may take up to 12 months
  • Curettage is needed if the x-rays show no healing after conservative management.
  • Curettage is also done along with open biopsy in doubtful cases.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy complains of pain in the left hip and knee. An X-ray of his left hip was obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given history and X-ray showing Trethowan's sign point to a diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). MRI scan is the investigation of choice for SCFE.

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign. Trethowan's sign is seen in this x-ray and thus the diagnosis is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). In SCFE, the slipping of the epiphysis usually occurs through the hypertrophic zone. Multiple endocrine disorders are often associated with SCFE, like hypothyroidism, osteodystrophy of chronic renal failure and excessive growth hormone. 

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

  • Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gunstock deformity of his hand which developed after he sustained a fracture. On examination, you notice that he was unable to perform the following sign and there were no associated sensory symptoms. This is suggestive of:

choices.text: Injury to the deep branch of ulnar nerve
Injury to the superficial branch of ulnar nerve
Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve
Injury to the anterior interosseous nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of gun stock deformity following a fracture indicates a history of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The sign shown in the above image is the 'OK sign' and the inability to perform this sign is suggestive of injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a purely motor branch of the median nerve. 

In the case of supracondylar fracture, the most common nerve injuries: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve

The patient is asked to perform the OK sign by touching the tips of the index finger and the thumb. Normally, the patient is able to flex the distal phalanges, producing an O-shape. 

In anterior interosseous nerve injury (AIN), the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus are weak. The patient is unable to perform the OK sign. The fingers get pinched, and instead of the tips, the volar surfaces of the thumb and index finger make contact.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient came with complaints of backache. On radiography, the following image is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hemangioma. The radiograph shows the vertebral body depicting vertical striations, giving a corduroy appearance.

Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. The atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion. Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.

Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance. On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas. 

The below CT image shows characteristic polka dot appearance (left) and corduroy appearance (right):

 

Other options:

Option A: Eosinophilic granuloma is a benign lesion of the vertebral body with a classic radiographic finding of vertebra plana, as shown below.

 

Option C: Paget disease is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by an increase in bone turnover at localized sites that is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. A radiograph of the vertebra gives a diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity that is referred to as the ivory vertebra appearance, as shown below.

 

Option D: Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disorder that is characterized by a low bone mass and defects in bone structure, thus rendering the bone unusually fragile and at greater risk of fracture compared to a person of the same age, sex, and race. On a vertebral radiograph, there is a biconcave appearance of the vertebra known as the codfish vertebra, as shown below.

questions.text: A patient presents with elbow deformity and forearm shortening after a fall. An X-ray was done and given below. What are the principles applied during the closed reduction of this condition?

choices.text: Traction along long axis of humerus and traction perpendicular to long axis of forearm
Traction along long axis of humerus and traction along long axis of forearm
Traction perpendicular to long axis of humerus and traction perpendicular to long axis of forearm
Traction perpendicular to long axis of humerus and traction along long axis of forearm

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of posterior dislocation of elbow. Stimson's 2 step principle is used for closed reduction in such conditions. 

The two steps are: 

  • step 1 - traction along long axis of humerus to counteract the contraction of biceps, triceps and brachialis
  • step 2 - traction along long axis of forearm to bring radius and ulna back into position

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a history of a minor fall. The affected limb is in extension and has slight external rotation. The radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is false about the condition?

choices.text: Malunion can happen if this condition is not treated
The patient may be able to walk
Shortening of limb is less than 1 inch

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and radiograph are suggestive of an impacted fractured neck of the femur, which is an intracapsular fracture. The neck of femur fractures almost never unite, hence nonunion is more likely to occur than malunion. 

Malunion is more likely to occur in inter-trochanteric or extracapsular fractures, as they are more likely to get displaced.

Neck of femur fractures can occur in the elderly age group due to a trivial fall, however, it is usually due to a more severe injury if it occurs in young adults. Patients have painful movements of the hip joint, but may be able to walk. On examination, there is tenderness in the hip, shortening of the limb <1 inch, and external rotation of the affected limb. Active straight leg raising is not possible.

Radiological features of this fracture include:

  • Break in the medial cortex of the neck
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter being more prominent
  • Overriding of the greater trochanter, so that it lies at the level of the head of the femur
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in the Shenton's line

In an impacted fracture, only bending of trabeculae may be visible.

Complications of fracture neck of the femur are non-union, avascular necrosis, and secondary osteoarthritis. Non-union occurs due to poor blood supply, inadequate reduction or fixation, and poor healing that occurs in intra-capsular fractures. 

After a fracture of the femoral neck, all the medullary blood supply and most of the capsular blood supply to the head are affected. Due to this diminished vascularity, avascular necrosis of a part or the entire femoral head commonly occurs. This can lead to non-union. MRI is the best investigation to diagnose avascular necrosis.

Impacted fractures can be treated conservatively or with screws if there is fear of fracture displacement. Displaced or unimpacted fractures are treated with internal fixation. In the elderly, the head is often excised and replaced with a prosthesis.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.solution:
Madelung deformity is an abnormality of the palmar ulnar part of the distal radial physis. In this, progressive ulnar and volar tilt develops at the distal articular surface of the radius with distal ulna dorsal subluxation.

Haglund deformity, pump bump or Mulholland deformity is seen in the ankle joint. It is a bony enlargement formed at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneum.

It is caused due to the chronic inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa. Recurrent pressure from the shoe may lead to the chronic inflammation of the bursa and calcification at the site of insertion of the Achilles tendon.

Malunion following supracondylar fracture most commonly leads to cubitus varus which is known as gunstock deformity.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male comes into the ER with pain around his ankle after twisting his ankle while playing football. Which of the following indicates the need for ankle X-rays according to Ottawa rules?

1 - Pain around the malleolus
2 - Numbness distal to the ankle
3 - Inability to bear weight on the ankle
4 - Bone tenderness at the posterior edge of the medial or lateral malleolus 
5 - Ability to take 10 steps in the ER
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of an ankle injury. The Ottawa ankle rules are used to determine the need for ankle X-rays in such cases.

The Ottawa ankle rules state that an x-ray is needed if any of the following conditions are met-

  1. Pain around the malleolar zone. 
  2. Bone tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral/medial malleolus/base of the 5th metatarsal bone. 
  3. An inability to bear weight immediately after the injury.
  4. Inability to walk 4 steps in the emergency department.

Acute injury of lateral ligaments of the ankle:

Clinical features -  Presents with a  history of a twisting injury. Pain and swelling may be present. A sprain is suspected if the patient is able to walk and bruising is only faint and slow to appear; a more severe injury is suspected if bruising is marked and the patient is unable to put any weight on the foot.

Investigation - X-ray is indicated based on the Ottawa ankle rules as mentioned above.

Treatment - Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE), which is recommended for 1–3 weeks. Protection in the form of crutches, splints, or brace may be added. Persistent problems at 12 weeks after injury, despite physiotherapy, may signal the need for operative treatment.

questions.text:
A patient who sustained a tibial fracture was managed conservatively with a plaster cast. A few days later, he presents with complaints of pain and paresthesia in the affected limb. On examination, severe pain was elicited on passive stretching. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding this condition?
  1. Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mmHg
  2. The earliest symptom to develop is paresthesia
  3. The fractures of the elbow and forearm are at high risk
  4. Paralysis of the muscle group is a late sign
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is suggestive of acute compartment syndrome and the true statements regarding this condition are 1, 3, and 4. Statement 2 is false because the earliest symptom to develop is pain and not paresthesia. 

Acute compartment syndrome can be defined as the elevation of intra-compartmental pressure that will cause tissue ischemia and necrosis without decompression. This occurs because increased pressure within a closed space in the body leads to a critical reduction of blood flow to the tissues.

The classic features of acute compartment syndrome include the 5 P's:

  • Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. It can be elicited on passive stretching of the muscles.
  • Paresthesia occurs due to the compression of nerves in the compartment and indicates nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor occurs due to ischemia.
  • Paralysis of muscle groups in the compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness is usually not seen in the early stages unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The injuries that are at high risk of developing acute compartment syndrome are the fractures of the elbow, forearm, proximal third of the tibia, and multiple fractures of the hand and foot. Other high-risk injuries are crush injuries and circumferential burns.

The intra-compartmental pressure (ICP) is measured using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. Earlier, the ICP values alone were used to determine the critical threshold for compartment syndrome. However, it was noted that different individuals had different levels of tolerance for raised ICP. Therefore, differential pressure is used now to determine the need for decompression.

Differential pressure (ΔP) is the difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure. When the ΔP is less than 30 mm Hg, the perfusion from blood vessels to the tissues is impaired. Hence, immediate compartment decompression/ fasciotomy is indicated.

All the dressings, bandages, and cast on the affected limb are removed and the limb is nursed flat. 

Fasciotomy wounds are left open. After 2 days, if there is necrosis, debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy, they can be sutured without tension. Alternatively, skin grafting can be done.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following about hallux valgus is false?

Angle between the first and second metatarsals is more than 8 to 9 degrees

questions.solution:

questions.text: An elderly post-menopausal woman presents with a history of wrist fracture 1 year ago and restriction of wrist movements. A diagnosis of malunited Colles' fracture is made. Which of the following would be the best modality of treatment to improve function in her case?

choices.text: Physiotherapy as nothing can be done due to her age

questions.solution:
Darrach's operation is the most common surgery done for malunited Colles' fracture. 

Darrach's operation involves excision of 2.5cm of the distal ulna along with the head leaving the periosteum behind. 

Management of malunited Colles is based on cosmetic or function desirability

  • in young adults who require cosmetic correction- Fernandez osteotomy or Campbell osteotomy
  • Elderly patient who require better function- Darrach’s operation

questions.text: All of the following are indications for Bone mineral density measurement except?

choices.text: Adults having a fracture at ≥ 45 years
Women aged ≥ 65 years irrespective of clinical risk factors
Men of age 50 to 69 years with clinical risk factors for fracture
Adults with an illness, associated with low bone mass

questions.solution:
Adults having a fracture at or after age 50 years and not 45 years is an indication for bone mineral density testing.
Bone mineral density (BMD) refers to the amount of minerals (calcium and phosphorous majorly) contained in a certain volume of bone.

Bone mineral density can be measured using several noninvasive techniques such as:

  1. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA)
  2. Single-energy x-ray absorptiometry (SXA)
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Ultrasound (USG)


Indications for BMD Testing include:

  1. Women aged ≥ 65 years and men aged ≥ 70 years irrespective of risk factors
  2. Adults having a fracture at ≥ 50 years
  3. Women in the menopausal transition, and men of age 50 to 69 years with risk factors for fracture
  4. Adults with an illness or taking medications such as glucocorticoids associated with low bone mass or bone loss

questions.text:
A 5-year-old male child presents with complaints of high-grade fever, pain in the right knee joint for more than a week, and a recent episode of sore throat. Examination reveals knee joint tenderness. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. X-ray showed a faint extracortical outline in the proximal tibia. Which of the following is false regarding the complications associated with this condition?

WBC - White blood cell

ESR - Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

CRP - C-reactive protein

choices.text: Suppurative arthritis can occur if the metaphysis is intra-articular
Pathological fractures are not commonly seen in this condition
Epiphyseal damage is commonly seen in elderly individuals
Psuedoarthrosis can occur at the hip joint in  infants

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis and epiphyseal damage is seen in neonates and infants.

Acute osteomyelitis

Causative organisms:

  • Staphylococcus is the most common organism causing osteomyelitis.
  • Pseudomonas is the most common cause in IV drug abusers
  • Salmonella is the most common cause in patients of sickle cell anemia
  • H.influenzae was a common causative organism in children, less common now because of vaccination
  • Streptococcus
  • E.coli

Route of infection: Acute osteomyelitis can be hematogenous or from exogenous routes such as open fractures, iatrogenic intervention, or spread from local infection.

Cardinal features of acute osteomyelitis in children include:

  • Fever
  • Pain
  • Refusal to bear weight
  • Elevated WBC count
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated ESR

X-ray findings:

  • During the first week, the X-ray appear to be normal and by the second week, a faint extracortical line may be visible due to periosteal new bone formation. This is a classic sign of early pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • A combination of regional osteoporosis with a localized segment of apparently increased density is an important late finding in this condition.

Management of acute osteomyelitis:

Collection of blood samples for culture and sensitivity test, followed by immediate empirical antibiotic therapy to prevent septicemia and other complications. 

Surgical drainage is indicated only in the following two circumstances

  • Presence of an abscess requiring drainage
  • Whenever the patient does not respond to antibiotics

Supportive therapy includes analgesics, IV fluids, and splinting of the limb.

The complications of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis include: 

  • Septicemia- Nowadays this is a rare complication due to prompt antibiotic therapy.
  • Epiphyseal damage and altered bone growth- This is seen in neonates and infants as their epiphyses are entirely cartilaginous. So the metaphysical vessels can penetrate into the physis and carry the infection to the epiphysis. In some cases involving the hip joint, the femoral head is so badly damaged and can lead to pseudoarthrosis.
  • Septic arthritis- It is seen when the metaphysics is intraarticular, in very young infants as the growth plate is penetrable, and from metastatic infection
  • Pathological fracture- It is an uncommon complication, but can occur if there is a treatment delay and a weakened bone due to erosion or overzealous debridement.
  • Chronic osteomyelitis

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents for a follow-up appointment after being diagnosed with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. His latest X-rays show ongoing skeletal growth. The orthopedic surgeon notes that the progression of his spinal curvature has started to slow down. At what grade of iliac apophyseal ossification is the progression of spinal curvature typically reduced?
questions.solution:
Risser's sign evaluates skeletal maturation using the ossification of the iliac apophysis in the evaluation of scoliosis. When fusion is complete, in grade 5, spinal maturity has been reached and the progression of spinal curvature is typically reduced. 

Risser's sign:

The iliac apophysis is divided into four quadrants. Ossification of iliac apophyses normally proceeds from the lateral to the medial side and from the anterior superior iliac spine to the posterior superior iliac spine. The Risser grades correspond to the degree of ossification, ranging from grade 0 (no ossification) to grade 4 (ossification of all four quadrants). When the apophysis has fused completely with the ilium, ossification is graded as Risser grade 5 and the patient is considered skeletally mature. 

Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS)

AIS is the most common type of scoliosis and develops in children over the age of 10 years until they reach skeletal maturity. It is asymptomatic and usually identified on routine physical examination. The spine may have deviated from the mid-line or a prominence may become apparent when the patient bends forward (the Adams test).

Confirmation of the diagnosis is through full-length lateral and PA X-rays. A Cobb angle of >10° is diagnostic. It is a measure of the degree of curvature using projected lines from the top of the uppermost and bottom of the lowermost vertebral bodies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient came to the OPD with a history of recurrent neck pain and stiffness over the last year.  He also has asymmetric bilateral loss of sensation in the lateral three digits. What is the likely etiology of the findings of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggestive of bilateral paresthesias and chronic neck pain are suggestive of cervical spondylosis.

Cervical spondylosis is a disorder arising due to chronic intervertebral disc degeneration in the cervical region. Changes are most common in lower cervical segments such as C5/6 and C6/7. The most common clinical feature is pain and stiffness of the neck. Involvement of different segments of the cervical spine can present with different sensory and motor symptoms. In this case, the presence of asymmetric bilateral loss of sensation in the lateral three digits indicates a compression at the C5/6 nerve root. In most cases, it is unilateral but can occur bilaterally.

The X-ray may show osteophytes and degenerative changes on Lateral view.

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment with analgesics, physiotherapy, and the cervical collar is the mainstay
  • Operative treatments performed include:
    • Anterior discectomy and fusion
    • Foraminotomy 
    • Intervertebral disc replacement
    • Laminoplasty

Other options:

Option A: Nerve entrapments can also present with pain and paresthesias but symptoms are worse at night and follow a particular peripheral nerve rather than a nerve root distribution. Also, bilateral loss of sensations is less likely in a nerve entrapment

Option B: A syrinx is a long cavity filled with CSF usually in the cervical spine. It is usually associated with trauma or tumors in the spine. It is less likely in this patient who is middle-aged. Age-related cervical degeneration should be ruled out first.

Option D: Cervical spine stenosis presents with upper motor neuron symptoms in the areas below the level of the stenosis. This patient has no such complaints making cervical spondylosis the likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms.

Related Pearl: Dermatome and root value of the upper limb

Key Sensory Areas:

  • C5 - Upper lateral part of arm
  • C6 - Palmar pad of thumb
  • C7 - Pad of index finger
  • C8 - Pad of little finger
  • T1 - Skin on medial aspect of elbow

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient is brought after a high-speed car collision. He sustained a fracture of the pelvis and left femur. In the ICU the following rash is noticed on the chest. His ABG shows a PaO2 of 54mmHg. What is the patient likely at risk for due to the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with multiple traumatic fractures including the femur, with a petechial rash as seen in the image has likely developed fat embolism syndrome. He is at risk for neurological deficits from occlusion of the small vessels of the brain due to fat globules.

Fat embolism syndrome is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after the fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. Its pathogenesis can be related to 2 factors:

  • The release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats that causes toxic vasculitis.
  • Actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

The early signs of fat embolism syndrome that occur within 72 hours of injury are fever and tachycardia. The presenting features can be classified into 2 types:

  • Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation, and coma
  • Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia

Pathognomic signs include a petechial rash in front of neck/anterior axillary fold/ chest/ conjunctiva

Fat embolism syndrome is diagnosed based on Gurd's diagnostic criteria:

  • Major criteria:
    • Petechial rash
    • PaO2 <60 mmHg
    • Central nervous system depression
  • Minor criteria
    • Pulse >110/minute
    • Pyrexia >38.5° C
    • Retinal embolism
    • Fat in urine
    • Reduced platelet count
    • Increased ESR
    • Fat globules in sputum
    • Drop-in hemoglobin
    • Fat macroglobulinemia

2 major criteria or 1 major criteria and 4 minor criteria are required for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome.

Management of fat embolism is mainly supportive. This consists of respiratory support with high inspired oxygen concentration, heparinization, intravenous low molecular weight dextran, and corticosteroids to reduce the inflammation in the lungs. Prompt stabilization of long-bone fractures reduces the incidence of fat embolism syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: While Torrential Hemorrhage can occur with pelvic and femoral fractures, the presence of a chest rash and hypoxemia are more indicative of fat embolism syndrome rather than hemorrhage.

Option B: Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery). This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. It is not a sequela of fat embolism syndrome. 

Option D: Acute compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis. It can occur following fractures(commonly) or soft tissue injuries and is a localized condition involving the affected limb. The clinical features include pain, paraesthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. However, ACS is not a sequela of fat embolism syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man involved in a fight injured his finger, and the deformity is as shown in the following image. You would suspect the diagnosis to be Mallet finger if you find the X-ray showing _________
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history of trauma and flexion at the DIP as seen in the clinical image, the diagnosis is mallet finger. It is due to the avulsion of the extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint by hyperflexion injury. As it occurs due to soft tissue injury, a radiograph will not show any bony abnormality, unless it is associated with an avulsion fracture.

It is treated by splinting the finger in hyperextension.

Jersey finger is caused by the rupture of flexor digitorum profundus from the distal phalanx. It occurs when there is hyperextension of the flexed finger trapped in a jersey.On Physical exam, finger lies in slight extension relative to other fingers in resting position and no active flexion of DIP is possible.

The following image shows splinting of the mallet finger.

Mallet finger is commonly known as baseball finger because the injury often happens when playing baseball.

Damage to the tendon occurs when a hard ball (that you’re trying to catch or field) hits your fingertip.

questions.text:
You are evaluating a 6-year-old boy who presented with a fever of 39°C and acute onset of a painful hip joint. On examination, the affected side has a complete inability of weight bearing. Blood investigation findings are given below. According to Kocher's criteria, what is the risk of septic arthritis in this child?

WBC - 15,000 cells/µL
ESR - 50 mm/h
CRP - 2.5 mg/L
questions.solution:
The clinical parameters in this child meet all 4 of Kocher's criteria, indicating a 99% risk of septic arthritis.

Kocher's criteria is used to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis. It assigns 1 point to each of these parameters:

  • Fever - >38.5°C 
  • WBC - >12000 cells/µL
  • ESR - >40 mm/h
  • Weight-bearing - complete inability

Based on the total number of points, the probability of septic arthritis is as follows:

  • 0 points: <0.2%
  • 1 point: 3%
  • 2 points: 40%
  • 3 points: 93%
  • 4 points: 99%.

Modified Kocher's criteria also includes CRP - >2.0 mg/L as one of the criteria.

questions.text:
Which of the following may be treated/may be achieved with the management modality demonstrated in the image below?

1 - Osteomyelitis
2 - Arthrodesis
3 - Nerve injury
4 - Limb lengthening
5 - Osteoporosis
questions.solution:
The management modality shown in the image is Ilizarov's technique. It is used in the following scenarios:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

Ilizarov's technique:

Distraction osteogenesis is the mechanical induction of new bone that occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. Ilizarov described this as “the tension stress effect.”

The most important application of the tension-stress principle is known as callus distraction (or callotaxis). A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator. 

Osteogenesis requires a dynamic state by either a controlled distraction or a controlled compression. This dynamic force causes dormant mesenchymal cells at the non-union site to differentiate into functioning osteoblasts. This results in bone synthesis and fracture healing. The fixation system is called a ring fixator.  Distraction or compression can be applied by twisting nuts on the fixation system at the fracture or corticotomy site.  Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. This is done in four sittings— ¼ mm, four times a day. This is used in limb lengthening or filling of large segmental defects in the bone.

questions.text: The given image shows the x-ray findings of a patient with osteitis deformans. In which phase of the disease are these findings seen?
questions.solution:

Osteitis deformans is also called Paget's disease of the bone. It is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas, resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity.

It is usually asymptomatic but can present with dull aching pain unless the disease is severe. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma.

Bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget’s disease.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient visits the OPD with progressive deformity in the left lower limb. The x-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the x-ray showing Shepherd's crook deformity are both suggestive of fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur. 

Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterized by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. It is commonly monostotic (involves a single bone), but in 20% of cases, it can be polyostotic.

Clinical features:

The patient presents with a progressive limb deformity or a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion. Presentation is often in the second decade. Other symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area. The commonly involved sites are the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

McCune-Albright syndrome: It is characterized by polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, precocious puberty, and cafe-au-lait spots with irregular borders.

Radiological findings:

  • Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions
  • Hazy, ground-glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases
  • Shepherd's crook deformity - Expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur

Treatment:

Bisphosphonates are used to manage bone pain. Surgical stabilization and realignment are done when there is a progressive deformity or pathological fracture. 

Other options: 

Option A: Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. It is most commonly seen in the diaphysis of the proximal femur. They most often present with pain that is classically worse at night and relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Plain X-ray demonstrates an area of dense sclerosis with a small rounded area of osteolysis. The preferred treatment is CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Option C: Chondrosarcoma is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It can present between the 3rd and 8th decades of life. They are slow-growing tumors that produce deep pain with an enlarging mass and arise in any bone derived from enchondral ossification. Radiographically, they appear as large, intraosseous, osteolytic tumors with irregular, granular calcifications, giving a honeycomb or popcorn appearance. CT and MRI are useful in the diagnosis. Chondrosarcoma is resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation. Surgical excision is the only treatment.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is related to neuroectodermal tumors and arises from the mesenchymal stem cells from the bone marrow. The characteristic translocation involved is t(11:22). The tumor usually develops between 10 and 20 years of age and is usually located in the diaphysis of the long bones (femur-most common). Pain is followed by swelling and a low-grade fever. On radiography, a periosteal reaction with an 'onion peel' appearance is seen. Treatment includes preoperative chemotherapy, wide excision, and radiotherapy, if required.

questions.text: An infant with growth retardation and hydrocephalus is found to have pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly on examination. He also has features of cranial nerve entrapment. What is the most probable radiographic sign seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the infantile form of osteopetrosis, in which the rugger jersey sign is seen on spine x-ray.

Osteopetrosis is due to defective osteoclastic activity. Excessive new bone formation with defective resorption leads to abnormal development of the skull, especially causing narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This leads to various complications such as hydrocephalus, cranial nerve compression leading to deafness and facial palsy, and sinus blockage. 

Failure of bone resorption results in a poorly formed medullary cavity. This leads to defective hematopoiesis in the medullary cavity and stimulation of extramedullary hematopoiesis. Hence, the infant presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly.

Radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae lead to rugger jersey appearance of vertebrae on the radiograph.

Note: Rugger jersey spine is also seen in renal osteodystrophy.

Option B: Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance in ankylosing spondylitis

Option C: A diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity is referred to as the ivory vertebra is seen in Paget's disease.

Option D: Codfish vertebra refers to the biconcave deformity of the vertebral body and is seen in osteoporosis or osteomalacia.

questions.text: A patient who sustained a talar fracture before 6 weeks now came for follow-up. His  X-Ray shows the presence of Hawkin's Sign.  What does this indicate?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of talus is likely
Avascular necrosis of calcaneum is unlikely
Avascular necrosis of talus is unlikely
Avascular necrosis of calcaneum is likely

questions.solution:
A patient who has sustained a talar fracture before 6 weeks and now showing Hawkin's sign in an X-ray of talus indicates avascular necrosis of talus is unlikely to develop.

Avascular necrosis/osteonecrosis is a complication that occurs following the fracture of the neck of the talus. It is seen in the body of the talus.

The earliest radiograph finding is the increased density of the avascular segment whereas the rest of the talus has become porotic due to disuse. Hawkin's sign indicates that the dome of the talus has become osteoporotic, implying it has a blood supply. This is looked at 6-8 weeks after the injury. 

If there is a dense segment of the talus bone after a few weeks of the talus fracture, it means there is an avascular segment. This is the earliest X-ray sign of avascular necrosis of the body of the talus. 

Weight-bearing should be delayed. Arthrodesis of the ankle is recommended when there is flattening or fragmentation of the talus. It can also be done when the pain and disability are marked. 

The X-ray below shows the presence of subchondral lucency or Hawkin's sign.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of abnormal gait. On examination, the child had a waddling gait and exaggerated lumbar lordosis. The mother gives a history of breech delivery and remembers that the pediatrician diagnosed a hip condition at that time, but it was ignored by the family. What should be the management at this stage?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of developmental or congenital dysplasia of the hip (DDH). In a child of age 18-36 months (2 years old), open reduction with osteotomy is done.

This osteotomy can be either femoral or pelvic or both. 

Pelvic osteotomies are of varieties as follows:

  • Salter's
  • Pemberton
  • Chiari
  • Steel
  • Shelf operations

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth.

Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in-utero predisposing it to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.
  • Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH
  • Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.
  • First born child.

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk".
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive Trendelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented to the casualty holding his right limb close to his chest. He gives a history of falling on his hand from the bike. His vitals are stable. On examination, the arm is abducted, externally rotated and the lateral outline of the shoulder is flattened. X-ray of his shoulder is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is an anterior shoulder dislocation.

The above clinical features of fall on the hands, the attitude of the arm, flattened lateral outline of the shoulder, and the radiograph showing the humeral head lying below and medial to the glenoid socket is suggestive of anterior shoulder dislocation.

The most common joint to dislocate is the shoulder joint. This is due to the shallowness of the glenoid socket, increased range of motion, underlying conditions like ligamentous laxity or glenoidal dysplasia, and vulnerability of the joint under stressful activities.

Anterior dislocation is the most common among shoulder dislocations. It occurs due to a fall on the hands. The head of the humerus is driven forwards and tears the capsule resulting in an avulsion in the glenoid labrum (Bankart lesion). Sometimes, the posterolateral part of the head of the humerus is crushed resulting in the Hill-Sachs lesion.

The clinical features include severe pain and the patient usually supports his dislocated arm with the opposite arm. On examination, the arm is usually abducted, externally rotated and the lateral outline of the shoulder may be straightened and sometimes a prominent acromion process or a bulge below the clavicle may be appreciated.

The anteroposterior radiograph shows the humeral head lying below and medial to the glenoid socket. It may also show the Bankart lesion and the Hill-Sachs lesion.

Below is the image of a radiograph showing Bankart lesion and Hill-Sachs lesion.

Other options:

Option A- Posterior shoulder dislocation is rare accounting for 2-4% of shoulder dislocations. It occurs due to axial loading on the adducted, internally rotated arm. It can also occur as a result of violent muscle contraction due to seizures or electrocution. The arm is adducted and internally rotated. An anteroposterior view radiograph of the shoulder shows an electric light bulb sign (abnormal shape of the humeral head) and an empty glenoid sign (humeral head is away from the glenoid fossa).

Below is the image showing the electric light bulb sign of posterior shoulder dislocation.

Options B and C: Inferior shoulder dislocation is also known as luxatio erecta. It occurs in less than 1% of cases. It is usually caused during severe hyperabduction of the arm or by axial loading on an abducted arm. On examination, the arm is held above the patient's head without being able to adduct the arm. The humeral head is felt below or in the axilla. The radiograph would reveal the humeral shaft in an abducted position with the humeral head below the glenoid fossa. 

Below is the image showing inferior shoulder dislocation.

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with bowed legs and growth retardation. The child has a history of inadequate sunlight exposure and a diet low in vitamin D. Despite supplementation with high-dose vitamin D, the child shows minimal improvement. Laboratory tests reveal normal serum calcium, low phosphate levels, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following findings would best differentiate non-nutritional rickets from nutritional rickets?

choices.text: Presence of widened osteoid seams on bone biopsy

questions.solution:
Elevated fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) levels are typically seen in non-nutritional rickets caused by genetic conditions like X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets

The fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) is a hormone that has a crucial role as a regulator of phosphate metabolism. FGF23 reduces phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubules and inhibits the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase, responsible for synthesizing active vitamin D (1,25(OH)2D). This hormone is produced primarily by osteocytes, and its levels are influenced by dietary phosphate intake. Elevated FGF23 levels are seen in genetic disorders like autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets (ADHR) and X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH), where mutations disrupt normal FGF23 regulation, leading to hypophosphatemia.

Option A. Elevated Parathyroid hormone levels are seen in Vitamin D-deficient rickets.

Option B. Presence of osteoid seams on bone biopsy is a common finding in both forms of rickets and doesn't specifically differentiate between nutritional and non-nutritional causes.

Option C. Low 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels: This is characteristic of nutritional rickets, where there is a deficiency in vitamin D.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He complains of pain in his left elbow. Examination reveals tenderness and swelling over his left elbow. An X-ray of the patient is given below. What is the fracture type according to the Gartland classification?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray showing posterior fat pad sign are suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus which is type 1 according to Gartland classification.

Gartland classification

  • Type I – an undisplaced fracture
  • Type II – an angulated fracture with the posterior cortex still intact.
             IIA: a less severe injury with the distal fragment merely angulated
             IIB: a severe injury; the fragment is both angulated and malrotated
  • Type III–a completely displaced fracture(although the posterior periosteum is usually preserved, which will assist in surgical reduction)
  • Type IV – an anteriorly displaced fracture

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

It is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. On examination:

There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there are blood vessel involvement.

Cubitus Varus deformity:

Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. The static deformities of cubitus varus with respect to the distal fragment are :

  • Posterior displacement
  • Horizontal rotation
  • Coronal tilt.

Treatment: 

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of the arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A boy is brought to the ER after he sustains a fall while playing. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling over his left elbow. His X-ray appears as given below. Conservative methods of management have failed and skeletal traction is suggested.  What is the appropriate site for inserting the skeletal traction in such cases?
questions.solution:
X-ray shows supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Skeletal traction in such cases is applied distal to the tip of the olecranon.

Interestingly, skeletal traction for intercondylar and comminuted fracture lower third of humerus are also done at the same site. 

Dunlop’s traction and Smith’s traction are skin tractions indicated for supracondylar fracture of the humerus. It is also used in intercondylar fractures of the humerus where elbow flexion causes circulatory embarrassment. 

Medial and lateral epicondyles have growth plates. Hence it would not be appropriate to insert skeletal traction at such sites.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman sustained crush injuries from a heavy machine 2 hours back. On catheterization, minimal dark brown colored urine was collected. Initial resuscitative measures were taken. When can the saline infusion be stopped in this patient?

choices.text: After myoglobin is undetected in urine
After myoglobin is doubled in urine
After Urine output has become normal

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Crush syndrome characterized by a crush injury, rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury. Aggressive intravenous volume replacement should be initiated. This should be continued until myoglobin is no longer detectable in the urine.

It can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Prolonged crushing of muscle leads to a reperfusion injury which releases myoglobin and vasoactive mediators into the circulation.

It also sequesters many liters of fluid, reducing the intravascular volume and resulting in renal vasoconstriction and ischemia. The myoglobinuria leads to renal failure from tubular obstruction.

Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

  Treatment:

  • Aggressive volume-loading of patients is the best treatment.
  • In adults, a saline infusion of 1000–1500mL per hour should be initiated. This should be continued until myoglobin is no longer detectable in the urine.
  • Mannitol administration can reduce the reperfusion component of this injury. Once a flow of urine is observed, mannitol–alkaline diuresis of up to 8 litres per day should be maintained, keeping the urinary pH greater than 6.5.
  • A late fasciotomy, when it is obvious that the muscles of that compartment must be dead, is only likely to cause a massive release of myoglobin and introduce infection into dead tissue. It therefore best not to perform a fasciotomy in cases where entrapment has been for over 12 hours.
  • Intensive care is required with close attention to fluid balance and renal dialysis if required.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old painter presented with chronic right shoulder pain. The physician performed a belly press test on the patient. Which of the following muscles is he specifically testing for?
questions.solution:
Belly press test is used to assess the subscapularis muscle.

In this test, the patient is asked to place their hand on the abdomen and bring their elbow forward, thus pressing the abdomen. If the subscapularis is torn the patient will not be able to do this, and thus, the elbow will move backward.

Apart from this, the lift-off test is also used to assess subscapularis muscle. In this test, the patient is asked to stand and place the dorsum of the hand against the mid-lumbar spine. The examiner then lifts this hand off the back and asks the patient to hold it right there. Inability to do so points towards the weakness of the subscapularis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with right anterior knee pain after sustaining an injury from bumping his flexed knee on a hard surface. On examination, shuttering is felt on palpating the medial side of the patella while flexing and extending the knee. MRI shows a low-intensity mass in the medial aspect of the knee. You confirm the diagnosis by performing an arthroscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 15-year-old boy presenting with anterior knee pain following trauma, with the presence of shuttering of the patella on examination and MRI showing a low-intensity mass in the medial aspect of the knee and confirmation of the diagnosis via arthroscopy, is suggestive of Plica syndrome.

A band of thick, fibrotic tissue that protrudes from a joint's synovial capsule is called a plica. Chronic irritation, overuse or trauma such as bumping the flexed knee on a hard surface can traumatise a plica, causing it to become sufficiently inflamed and thickened to produce symptoms.

The knee is divided into 3 compartments by synovial membranes during foetal development which resolve to form a single cavity by 4 to 5 months of development. Incomplete or partial resorption results in incomplete synovial folds or plicae. The synovial plicae are commonly described as infrapatellar (most common), suprapatellar, medial and lateral.

One of the main symptoms of plica syndrome is anterior knee pain. A pathologic plica that snaps across the patella or medial femoral condyle causes popping and catching in the knee. Symptoms are aggravated by exercise or climbing stairs.

The Shutter test helps in diagnosing plica syndrome. Here the patient sits at the edge of the examination table, hanging their legs at a 90° angle. The examiner places his finger over the medial side of the patella of the affected leg while the patient extends his knee. The test is positive if the examiner detects "stuttering" of the patella which occurs as a result of flipping of the abnormal plica over the medial femoral condyle.

The most effective way to diagnose abnormal plica is through arthroscopic knee examination. Plicae are only occasionally seen on MRI and are more noticeable when there is effusion, where they appear with low signal intensity. Symptomatic plicae are thicker than normal plicae, which are thin.

Initial treatment should include conservative measures like restriction of activities, use of anti-inflammatory medications and intraarticular corticosteroid injections. When conservative measures fail, surgical excision by arthroscopic technique is done.

Other options:

Option A:  Osteochondritis dissecans is a condition characterized by an area of subchondral bone that becomes necrotic and the cartilage overlying it undergoes degenerative changes. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies. On a radiograph, they appear as oval lucent areas adjacent to the articular margin. 

Option B: Osgood-Schlatter disease refers to apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity that occurs due to persistent traction on the tibial tuberosity. The condition is associated with overuse and is often seen in those playing basketball and volleyball. They present with pain and swelling over the tibial tubercle. 

Option C: Hoffa’s disease is the impingement and inflammation of the infrapatellar fat pad. It is characterized by anterior knee pain. The radiographic image shows increased density in the infrapatellar pad of fat or Hoffa's fat pad.

choices.text: Non-union is the most common complication
Undisplaced fractures are managed with a sling

questions.solution:
The given image shows a clavicular fracture of the middle third of the clavicle. Non-union is a relatively rare complication in clavicle shaft fracture. 

One of the most frequently fractured bones in the body is the clavicle. Mostly it occurs due to a direct blow or a fall on an outstretched arm. The midshaft of the clavicle is most commonly fractured. The lateral fragment is pulled down by the weight of the arm and the medial half is pulled up by the sternomastoid muscle. 

The patient will be presented with the flexed elbow as the arm will be held to the chest to prevent movement. It is divided into three based on the location of the fractures:

  1. Group I – middle-third fractures
  2. Group II – lateral-third fractures
  3. Group III – medial-third fractures.

Treatment of clavicle fractures:

  • Undisplaced fractures are treated with a sling or figure of eight bandages for 2-3 weeks. This is followed by mobilization of the limb as the pain subsides.
  • Displaced fractures are treated with internal fixation either by contoured locking plates or intramedullary nails (shown below).

Malunion is the most common complication in clavicle fractures. Fractures occur mostly in the middle one-third of the clavicle shaft.
