questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by a 'ray pattern' where all joints of the same digit are involved while the adjacent digit is spared or a 'row pattern' when there is a predilection for the distal interphalangeal joint and sparing of the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
In psoriatic arthritis, joint involvement tends to follow 'ray' and 'row' patterns. Ray distribution refers to the involvement of all the joints of one finger while the adjacent finger is totally spared. Row pattern is predilection for the distal interphalangeal joint and sparing of the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age. The disease is equally prevalent in males & females. Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints. Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). The distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is the most common joint involved in psoriatic arthritis. 

 

 A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis, or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

  1. Current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis
  2. Typical psoriatic nail involvement
  3. Rheumatoid factor negative
  4. Current or history of dactylitis
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Triggers include trauma to a joint or tendon (Koebner effect), smoking, alcohol excess, and HIV infection. 

Clinical features include:

  • Asymmetric joint involvement - most common presentation
  • Early morning stiffness
  • Swollen, tender, one or more joints
  • Enthesitis: Heel pain due to Achilles tendon inflammation
  • Plantar fasciitis
  • Dactylitis/ sausage fingers with telescoping (shortening of toes due to osteolysis)
  • Nail changes: hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
  • Axial involvement may occur

Inflammatory markers like CRP and ESR are elevated. Plain x‐rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease, showing:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'

NSAIDs, steroid injections, methotrexate, and cyclosporin/ biologicals can be used for the management of this condition. Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Psoriatic arthritis is found to be associated with ocular diseases like conjunctivitis, uveitis, iridocyclitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca and cataracts, obesity/ metabolic syndrome, alcohol misuse, and premature cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: An orthopaedic surgeon while performing a transfemoral amputation, stabilises the adductor magnus tendon by suturing it to the lateral cortex of the distal femur. In which of the following cases is this method contraindicated?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of transfemoral amputation, the procedure of stabilising the adductor magnus tendon by suturing it to the lateral cortex of the distal femur is suggestive of myodesis, which is contraindicated in cases of ischemia.

During amputation, muscles are usually divided at least 5 cm distal to the level of the bone. They may be stabilized by myodesis or myoplasty.

Myodesis involves suturing the distal tendon through pre-drilled holes in the bone to secure the muscle to the bone. They minimise atrophy, help maximise strength, and offer a stronger insertion. Myodesed muscles continue to counterbalance their antagonists, preventing contractures and maximizing residual limb function.

However, due to concerns of blood flow restriction and jeopardising an already precarious blood supply, myodesis is contraindicated in ischemic limbs like in peripheral vascular disease (PVD) amputations.

Myoplasty involves suturing the muscle to the periosteum or the fascia of opposing musculature. This can be done in PVD amputations.

questions.text:
Match the following with the best mode of management:
1. Osteosarcoma  a. Wide excision
2. Simple bone cyst  b. Curettage 
3. Giant cell tumor c. Radiofrequency ablation 
4. Osteoid osteoma  d. Intralesional steroid
questions.solution:
Option C is the correct answer. The given lesions and the correctly matched best modes of management are as follows:

Bone tumor Management

1. Osteosarcoma

 a. Wide excision
2. Simple bone cyst d. Intralesional steroid 
3. Giant cell tumor b. Curettage
4. Osteoid osteoma c. Radiofrequency ablation 

Osteosarcoma: It is a high-grade medullary osteoid-producing tumor. Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The preferred method of treatment of osteosarcoma is wide resection and reconstruction. This is mainly owing to the possibility of limb salvage, and amputation is considered only when tumor-safe surgical margins are compromised.

Multi-agent neoadjuvant chemotherapy with agents like doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate is started immediately after diagnosis for 8-12 weeks. The tumor is then re-staged followed by wide resection and limb reconstruction. 

Radiographic findings: The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray. It is shown in the image below.

Simple bone cyst: These are cystic bone cavities that are often solitary and unilocular filled with serous or serosanguinous material. The lesions usually regress with bone maturity. In cases where the lesions are active, injection of steroids is done. Only when there is a high risk of fracture, curettage, or fixation and stabilization may be required. 

It is seen as a well-outlined lytic centrally placed lesion with cortical thinning on X-ray. When there is a fracture, a small fragment may be visualized within the cavity, known as the fallen leaf sign. The image below shows a bone cyst in the humerus along with a pathological fracture and fallen leaf sign 

Giant cell tumor: It is a benign, locally aggressive tumor of the bone due to the proliferation of mononuclear cells with scattered macrophages. They are noticed mostly when there is cortical erosion with or without soft tissue compromise (stages 2 or 3). 

In stages 1 and 2, intralesional curettage with debridement of the lesional wall is effective. Stage 3 of the disease can be treated through curettage but some cases require en-bloc resection. Antibodies like denosumab (anti-RANKL) have been effective in controlling osteoclastic activity. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the metaphyses
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Below image shows Soap bubble appearance seen in giant cell tumor.

Osteoid osteoma: It is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. The preferred method of treatment in this condition is CT-guided radiofrequency ablation to eradicate the lesion and improve symptoms.

Radiography shows a sclerotic peripheral rim with central radiolucent nidus.

questions.text:
Arrange the following deformities in the order that they occur during the clinical course of tuberculosis of the hip.
  1. Flexion, adduction, apparent shortening
  2. Fibrous ankylosis
  3. Flexion, abduction, apparent lengthening
  4. Flexion, adduction, true shortening
  5. Pestle and mortar deformity
questions.solution:
The clinical course of tuberculosis of the hip has been divided into the following stages:

  1. Stage of synovitis presents with flexion, abduction, external rotation, and apparent lengthening of the limb due to joint effusion.
  2. Stage of early arthritis presents with flexion, adduction, internal rotation, and apparent shortening of the limb.
  3. Stage of advanced arthritis presents with the same deformities as early arthritis, except there is a true shortening of the limb because of the destruction of the articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.
  4. Stage of advanced arthritis with subluxation leads to destruction of acetabulum and dislocation of the femur head. This is also known as wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip.
  5. Tuberculosis of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male patient presents with pain and swelling around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. Choose the correct statements regarding his condition.
  1. Radiotherapy is a commonly used treatment modality.
  2. The lesion is usually present in the epiphysis of the bone.
  3. It is associated with periosteal reaction.
  4. A biopsy of the lesion is mandatory before starting treatment.
  5. CT scan of the chest is mandatory during the workup.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the X-ray image showing sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is associated with a periosteal reaction, and a biopsy of the lesion and CT scan of the chest are mandatory steps during the workup of the patient. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone, with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade. The most common site involved is the metaphysis (statement 2) of distal femur and proximal tibia.

X-rays features include:

  • Codman’s triangle → due to new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation
  • Sunburst appearance → due to new bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor
  • Periosteal reaction (statement 3) occurs due to the lifting of the periosteum of the bone. Periosteal reaction in osteosarcoma is irregular, unlike in osteomyelitis where it is smooth. 

A biopsy of the tumor should always be carried out before starting treatment (statement 4). The biopsy tract has to be removed during definitive surgery. CT scan of the chest is also mandatory in all cases of osteosarcoma (statement 5) because lung metastases at the time of presentation are common.

Treatment is by wide excision and reconstruction if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. There is no role of radiotherapy in the treatment of osteosarcoma (statement 1). Limb salvage surgeries are preferred over amputation. The principal first-line chemotherapeutic agents used in osteosarcoma are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.
